Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Photothermally-Enabled Multifunctional Membranes for Improved Foulant Resistance during Reverse Osmosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1604542
Jun

Fresh water demands of growing populations are driving the search for advanced membrane technologies for desalination and water reuse projects. The longevity of these membranes is strongly related to their resistance to fouling. In this work, the PIs will develop two new multifunctional membranes which have the potential to minimize fouling and, therefore, extend the lifetime of the membranes.

The proposed photothermally-active nanostructure-enabled reverse osmosis membranes are highly innovative, potentially transformative, and, quite promising for water treatment. For the first time, gold (Au) nanostars- and chemically exfoliated-MoS2-enabled photothermally-active membranes will be tested for their bactericidal efficacy as well as their inorganic and organic fouling resistance. In particular, this work investigates the unexplored potential of inexpensive and earth-abundant MoS2 as a replacement for expensive materials to achieve water sustainability. Because chemically exfoliated-MoS2 is a highly promising 2D optical and electronic material, new information about water chemically exfoliated-MoS2 interfacial reactions will also help design safer and more sustainable nanomaterials. Furthermore, the proposed research will elucidate scientific principles underlying the in situ nucleation and growth of gold (Au) nanostars and their photothermal effects on membranes. It will define the substrates and nanostructures surface chemistry (i.e., their chemical nature, surface charge, hydrophilicity, and morphology) in highly saline solutions. These lessons can also advance our understanding of the complex fouling behavior of other membrane systems. In addition, the wide array of nanoscale characterization techniques for nanostructures in solution and on substrate surfaces can lead to novel synthetic routes for size- and shape-controlled nanomaterials. Creating unique nanostructures that can be light-activated to maximize bactericidal functionality is an innovative and transformative approach towards addressing a major global challenge. The proposed teaching and outreach plan will provide educational and research opportunities for middle school, undergraduate, and graduate students.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Prof. Young-Shin Jun (PI) and Prof. Srikanth Singamaneni (co-PI) conducted a National Science Foundational Environmental Engineering project (CBET-1604542) to develop photothermally-enabled membranes for clean water production.

Intellectual merit: The fresh water demands of growing populations are driving the search for advanced membrane technologies for desalination and water reuse. The longevity of these membranes is strongly related to their foulant resistance. In this work, the project team developed new photothermally-enabled multifunctional membranes that incorporate photothermally-active nanoscale materials to effectively absorb light and convert it into heat. The generated heat can be used for water distillation and microbial disinfection. In Year 1, the team investigated AuNS-enabled photothermally-active membranes for their bactericidal efficacy as well as their inorganic and organic fouling resistance. Then, based on this improved understanding, in Years 2 and 3, the team investigated the unexplored potential of inexpensive 2D nanostructures as a replacement for expensive Au materials. In Year 3, the team focused on environmentally-benign and biocompatible and biodegradable photothermal materials and their incorporation into the photothermal membrane materials. In Year 4, with a no cost extension, the team examined the thermal engineering of the membranes.  For example, a thermally dissimilar bilayer membrane can significantly lower the conductive heat transfer across the membrane, significantly enhancing thermal efficiency.  Moreover, a better understanding of the substrates' and nanostructures' surface chemistry -- their chemical nature, surface charge, hydrophilicity, and morphology -- in highly saline solutions was achieved. These lessons can advance our understanding of the complex fouling behavior of other membrane systems. In addition, the wide array of nanoscale characterization techniques for nanostructures in solution and on substrate surfaces can lead to novel synthetic routes for size- and shape-controlled nanomaterials.

Six accomplishments have been achieved thus far:

  1. We introduced in situ growth-mediated bacterial nanocellulose (BNC)-based nanocomposites as highly efficient and tunable membranes.
  2. We designed, realized, and extensively tested nanocomposite membranes made of BNC and functional nanomaterials (such as reduced graphene oxide, MoS2 nanosheets, and polydopamine nanoparticles and coatings) for highly efficient solar steam generation and membrane distillation.
  3. We demonstrated photothermally-active ultrafiltration membranes that harness sunlight to kill microorganisms on the membrane surface, thus overcoming membrane biofouling.
  4. We introduced environmentally-benign, biocompatible, and completely biodegradable membranes based on natural materials.
  5. We demonstrated a facile and scalable polydopamine and BNC membrane that can efficiently remove a variety of metal ions and organic dyes from contaminated water.
  6. We provided new, more energy efficient photothermal membrane systems by incorporating thermally engineered membrane structures and heat recovery.

In particular, the project findings are important in developing countries and resource-limited regions, where no power infrastructure or waste heat from industrial plants is available. The photothermal membranes and the photothermal-driven membrane distillation (PMD) modules developed in this project are highly innovative, and they provide attractive and sustainable technology for freshwater generation. The knowledge generated by the project can accelerate the development of low-cost, low-energy desalination/water filtration systems, distinguished by high water flux and foulant rejection, that can maintain a cleaner membrane surface by photothermal activation of surface nanostructures.

Overall, this project has resulted in 17 peer-reviewed publications, one paper in review, and three patent applications. The results have been disseminated through 14 invited lectures and 21 contributed presentations at national and international meetings. Two of the publications were featured on the covers of Environmental Science & Technology and Accounts of Chemical Research. 

Broader Impacts: The novel materials, processes, and technologies developed within the scope of this project are highly scalable, environmentally-friendly, and can contribute greatly to alleviating water scarcity in both urban and rural communities. In addition to the technological broader impacts, the project's teaching and outreach activities provided educational and research opportunities for middle school, undergraduate, and graduate students. As an early step in promoting STEM careers, the project team helped develop a teaching curriculum for the local middle school. The team consulted with outreach educators at Washington University's Institute for School Partnership (ISP) on the development of educational modules on water treatment. The PIs hosted high school student interns in their labs during summers, and students worked in the PIs' labs to improve their knowledge of nanoscience, nanotechnology, and environmental engineering, as well as their understanding of water treatment processes. The PIs particularly recruited students from underrepresented groups to work together on the engineering design of membranes for water treatment processes. Educational activities were evaluated periodically and improved. The project provided research and educational opportunities for six doctoral students, seven undergraduate students, and three high school students.

Modified by: Young-Shin Jun

Images (1 of )
  • The novel design and in situ incorporation of reduced graphene oxide into bacterial nanocellulose membranes present excellent biofouling resistance by localized heating of the membrane's surface through photothermal effects.
    Young-Shin Jun and Srikanth Singamaneni
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    anti-biofouling membrane
  • Chemically exfoliated (ce) MoS2 nanosheets were mechanically interlocked with bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) for use in solar thermal water purification. The phase transition from 2H to 1T during exfoliation enhanced the light absorption of ce-MoS2, increasing the solar evaporation efficiency.
    Young-Shin Jun and Srikanth Singamaneni
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    MoS2 solar interfacial evaportator
  • newly synthesized photothermal membrane image
    Young-Shin Jun and Srikanth Singamaneni
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    photothermal membrane image
  • Using a new multi-layer stacked membrane distillation, the performance of the photothermal membrane distillation was largely improved by latent heat recovery, achieving 105% solar efficiency.
    Young-Shin Jun
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    multi-layer stacked photothermal membrane distillation
  • Using renewable solar energy, a thermally-engineered, highly porous, and environmentally-sustainable photothermal membrane that consists of polydopamine-bacterial nanocellulose bilayer achieves energy-efficient photothermal membrane distillation and effective photothermal interfacial disinfection
    Young-Shin Jun and Srikanth Singamaneni
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    A Thermally Engineered Polydopamine and Bacterial Nanocellulose Bilayer Membrane for Photothermal Membrane Distillation with Bactericidal Capability
  • Professor Jun and her Ph.D. students offered two outreach activities (a hands-on Workshop on �Moving and Shaking: An Introduction to Environmental Science and Engineering� for students in K 6-8, and a workshop on Environmental Engineering for high school students and teachers).
    Young-Shin Jun
    Copyrighted
    Young-Shin Jun
    Outreach activity
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Prof. Young-Shin Jun (PI) and Prof. Srikanth Singamaneni (co-PI) conducted a National Science Foundational Environmental Engineering project (CBET-1604542) to develop photothermally-enabled membranes for clean water production. Intellectual merit: The fresh water demands of growing populations are driving the search for advanced membrane technologies for desalination and water reuse. The longevity of these membranes is strongly related to their foulant resistance. The generated heat can be used for water distillation and microbial disinfection. In Year 1, the team investigated AuNS-enabled photothermally-active membranes for their bactericidal efficacy as well as their inorganic and organic fouling resistance. Then, based on this improved understanding, in Years 2 and 3, the team investigated the unexplored potential of inexpensive 2D nanostructures as a replacement for expensive Au materials. In Year 3, the team focused on environmentally-benign and biocompatible and biodegradable photothermal materials and their incorporation into the photothermal membrane materials. In Year 4, with a no cost extension, the team examined the thermal engineering of the membranes. Moreover, a better understanding of the substrates' and nanostructures' surface chemistry -- their chemical nature, surface charge, hydrophilicity, and morphology -- in highly saline solutions was achieved. These lessons can advance our understanding of the complex fouling behavior of other membrane systems. In addition, the wide array of nanoscale characterization techniques for nanostructures in solution and on substrate surfaces can lead to novel synthetic routes for size- and shape-controlled nanomaterials. Six accomplishments have been achieved thus far: We introduced in situ growth-mediated bacterial nanocellulose (BNC)-based nanocomposites as highly efficient and tunable membranes. We designed, realized, and extensively tested nanocomposite membranes made of BNC and functional nanomaterials (such as reduced graphene oxide, MoS2 nanosheets, and polydopamine nanoparticles and coatings) for highly efficient solar steam generation and membrane distillation. We demonstrated photothermally-active ultrafiltration membranes that harness sunlight to kill microorganisms on the membrane surface, thus overcoming membrane biofouling. We introduced environmentally-benign, biocompatible, and completely biodegradable membranes based on natural materials. We demonstrated a facile and scalable polydopamine and BNC membrane that can efficiently remove a variety of metal ions and organic dyes from contaminated water. We provided new, more energy efficient photothermal membrane systems by incorporating thermally engineered membrane structures and heat recovery. The photothermal membranes and the photothermal-driven membrane distillation (PMD) modules developed in this project are highly innovative, and they provide attractive and sustainable technology for freshwater generation. The knowledge generated by the project can accelerate the development of low-cost, low-energy desalination/water filtration systems, distinguished by high water flux and foulant rejection, that can maintain a cleaner membrane surface by photothermal activation of surface nanostructures. Overall, this project has resulted in 17 peer-reviewed publications, one paper in review, and three patent applications. The results have been disseminated through 14 invited lectures and 21 contributed presentations at national and international meetings. Two of the publications were featured on the covers of Environmental Science & Technology and Accounts of Chemical Research. Broader Impacts: The novel materials, processes, and technologies developed within the scope of this project are highly scalable, environmentally-friendly, and can contribute greatly to alleviating water scarcity in both urban and rural communities. In addition to the technological broader impacts, the project's teaching and outreach activities provided educational and research opportunities for middle school, undergraduate, and graduate students. As an early step in promoting STEM careers, the project team helped develop a teaching curriculum for the local middle school. The team consulted with outreach educators at Washington University's Institute for School Partnership (ISP) on the development of educational modules on water treatment. The PIs hosted high school student interns in their labs during summers, and students worked in the PIs' labs to improve their knowledge of nanoscience, nanotechnology, and environmental engineering, as well as their understanding of water treatment processes. The PIs particularly recruited students from underrepresented groups to work together on the engineering design of membranes for water treatment processes. Educational activities were evaluated periodically and improved. The project provided research and educational opportunities for six doctoral students, seven undergraduate students, and three high school students.
